newsitem.title: POLAND: POLISH PENSIONS TO GROW BY 8.2 PCT IN MARCH. [CORRECTED 15:00 GMT]
newsitem.headline: POLISH PENSIONS TO GROW BY 8.2 PCT IN MARCH. [CORRECTED 15:00 GMT]

text.p: Poland's state-owned Social Security Office (ZUS) will raise the average pension by 42 zlotys to 557 zlotys plus a one-off 50 zloty March bonus to compensate for higher-than-planned inflation last year, PAP news agency said. (Corrects headline and text to make clear the rise will be 42 zlotys not 92 zlotys while the remaining 50 zlotys is a one-off bonus).

PAP quoted ZUS president Anna Bankowska as saying on Wednesday that pensions had increased by 1.8 percent in real terms last year and not by 2.5 percent as envisaged by the 1996 national budget and hence the need for the compensation.
According to the 1997 budget, pensions are to rise by 1.5 percent in real terms.

But their growth is likely to be higher after the March increase and another rise planned in July, which stems from a constitutional court ruling that the government had illegally denied pensioners rises in 1992.
Inflation in 1996 was 18.5 percent in year-on-year terms.
